solution_line_template: As the number of cakes doubles each day, Marjorie must have made {cakes_on_sixth_day} cakes / {doubling_factor} = <<{cakes_on_sixth_day}/{doubling_factor}={cakes_on_fifth_day}>>{cakes_on_fifth_day} cakes on the fifth day.
So on the fourth day, she must have made {cakes_on_fifth_day} cakes / {doubling_factor} = <<{cakes_on_fifth_day}/{doubling_factor}={cakes_on_fourth_day}>>{cakes_on_fourth_day} cakes.
This means that on the third day, she made {cakes_on_fourth_day} cakes / {doubling_factor} = <<{cakes_on_fourth_day}/{doubling_factor}={cakes_on_third_day}>>{cakes_on_third_day} cakes.
On the second day, she made {cakes_on_third_day} cakes / {doubling_factor} = <<{cakes_on_third_day}/{doubling_factor}={cakes_on_second_day}>>{cakes_on_second_day} cakes.
So on the first day, she made {cakes_on_second_day} cakes / {doubling_factor} = <<{cakes_on_second_day}/{doubling_factor}={cakes_on_first_day}>>{cakes_on_first_day} cakes.
